Title: Which functional form best describes confidence decline over 6 days in VR episodic memory?
Hypothesis: Exploratory analysis comparing 5 candidate models (Linear, Quadratic, Logarithmic, Linear+Logarithmic, Quadratic+Logarithmic) for confidence trajectories. Expected: Logarithmic model best (paralleling Ch5 accuracy findings). Akaike weight > 0.30 for best model. Rationale: If confidence tracks accuracy, both should show rapid early decline followed by asymptotic leveling.
Data_Required: Source: data/cache/dfData.csv. Variables: UID, TEST, TSVR (hours), TC_* confidence items (5-level Likert: 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0). Sample: N=100 participants x 4 tests = 400 observations. Transformations: Days = TSVR_hours/24, Days_squared, log_Days_plus1. Note: TC_ tags are 5-category ordinal, NOT dichotomous like TQ_.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract VR data, filter to TC_* confidence items for omnibus "All" factor. (1) IRT Pass 1: GRM (Graded Response Model) for 5-category ordinal data, single factor, p1_med prior. (2) Item purification (Decision D039): exclude items with |b| > 3.0 OR a < 0.4. (3) IRT Pass 2 re-calibration on purified items. (4) Merge theta_confidence with TSVR, create time transformations. (5) Fit 5 LMMs with REML=False: Linear, Quadratic, Logarithmic, Lin+Log, Quad+Log; all with random slopes by UID. (6) Model selection via AIC, compute Akaike weights. (7) Compare to Ch5 accuracy model selection (5.1.1).
Expected_Output: data/step00_irt_input.csv; data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv; data/step02_purified_items.csv; data/step03_theta_confidence.csv (400 rows); data/step04_lmm_input.csv (400 rows); results/step05_model_comparison.csv (5 models); data/step06_best_model.pkl; results/step06_aic_comparison.csv; results/step07_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: IRT convergence: theta in [-4,4], SE in [0.1,1.5]. GRM for 5-category data (NOT 2PL). Purification: 30-70% retention. All 5 LMMs converge. Akaike weights sum to 1.0. Best model weight > 0.30. Comparison to Ch5 5.1.1 documented.

Title: Does confidence decline show the same two-phase pattern (rapid early, slow late) as accuracy?
Hypothesis: Confidence exhibits two-phase pattern paralleling accuracy: rapid decline Day 0->1, slower decay Day 1->6. Evidence: (1) significant quadratic term (p < 0.01 Bonferroni), (2) piecewise model AIC < continuous by > 2, (3) Late/Early slope ratio < 0.5. Rationale: Sleep-dependent consolidation should affect metacognitive monitoring similarly to memory traces.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.1.1: results/ch6/6.1.1/data/step03_theta_confidence.csv, results/ch6/6.1.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv. Sample: N=100, 400 observations. Segments: Early (0-48h), Late (48-144h). Compare to Ch5 5.1.2 pattern.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load theta_confidence from RQ 6.1.1. (1) Create piecewise time variables (48h breakpoint). (2) Test 1: Fit quadratic model, test Time^2 significance (Bonferroni alpha=0.01). (3) Test 2: Fit piecewise model, compare AIC to continuous. (4) Test 3: Compute Early/Late slope ratio. (5) Compare pattern to Ch5 5.1.2 (accuracy two-phase).
Expected_Output: results/step02_quadratic_model_summary.txt; results/step03_piecewise_comparison.csv; results/step04_slope_ratio.csv; results/step05_ch5_comparison.csv; plots/step06_twophase_theta_data.csv
Success_Criteria: All models converge. 2/3 tests support two-phase pattern (or NULL replicating accuracy). Comparison to Ch5 5.1.2 documented. Plot data complete.

Title: Does age affect baseline confidence or confidence decline rate?
Hypothesis: Age will NOT significantly affect confidence decline rate, paralleling Ch5 null findings (5.1.3, 5.2.3, 5.3.4, 5.4.3 all NULL). Expected: Age_c on intercept may be marginal (older adults may be less confident overall), but Age_c × Time interaction NULL (p > 0.05). Rationale: VR ecological encoding creates age-invariant forgetting; metacognitive monitoring should parallel.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.1.1: results/ch6/6.1.1/data/step03_theta_confidence.csv, results/ch6/6.1.1/data/step00_tsvr_mapping.csv. Age from data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: N=100, 400 observations. Transformations: Age_c (centered), log_TSVR.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load theta_confidence + Age. (1) Center Age. (2) Fit LMM: theta ~ (Time + Time_log) × Age_c + (Time | UID). (3) Extract Age_c main effect and interaction terms, Bonferroni alpha=0.0167. Report dual p-values (D068). (4) Effect size at Day 6. (5) Age tertile plot. (6) Compare to Ch5 5.1.3.
Expected_Output: data/step01_lmm_input.csv; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; data/step03_age_effects.csv (dual p-values); results/step04_effect_size.csv; plots/step05_age_tertile_data.csv; results/step06_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. Age_c centered. Dual p-values present. Comparison to Ch5 5.1.3 (expect NULL replication). Plot: 12 rows (3 tertiles × 4 tests).

Title: Is confidence decline trait-like or state-like? Does 5-level data reveal slope variance that dichotomous accuracy missed?
Hypothesis: CRITICAL HYPOTHESIS: ICC_slope for confidence > 0.10 (detectable with 5-level ordinal data) while Ch5 accuracy ICC_slope ≈ 0 (dichotomous data limitation). Rationale: 5-level Likert provides 2.3× more information per response than 0/1. If ICC_slope_confidence > 0.10 but ICC_slope_accuracy ≈ 0, proves dichotomous data limited slope detection. If ICC_slope_confidence ≈ 0 too, confirms forgetting rate truly shows minimal trait variance.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.1.1: results/ch6/6.1.1/data/step06_best_model.pkl. Sample: N=100, 400 observations. Compare directly to Ch5 5.1.4 ICC values.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load best LMM from RQ 6.1.1. (2) Extract variance components: var_intercept, var_slope, cov_int_slope, var_residual. (3) Compute ICC_intercept, ICC_slope_simple, ICC_slope_conditional at Day 6. (4) Extract 100 participant random effects. (5) Test intercept-slope correlation. (6) CRITICAL: Compare ICC_slope_confidence vs Ch5 ICC_slope_accuracy (0.0005). Test if significantly higher.
Expected_Output: data/step02_variance_components.csv; data/step03_icc_estimates.csv; data/step04_random_effects.csv (100 rows, REQUIRED for 6.1.5); data/step05_intercept_slope_correlation.csv; results/step06_ch5_icc_comparison.csv (CRITICAL); results/step06_interpretation.txt
Success_Criteria: ICC in [0,1]. 100 random effects extracted. Intercept-slope correlation tested. CRITICAL: Ch5 comparison documented (ICC_slope_accuracy = 0.0005 vs ICC_slope_confidence = ?). Interpretation of design vs measurement effect.

Title: Do participants cluster into confidence phenotypes, and do they match accuracy phenotypes?
Hypothesis: Expected 2-3 profiles paralleling Ch5 5.1.5 (Resilient vs Vulnerable). If confidence and accuracy phenotypes match, suggests integrated memory-metacognition system. If divergent, suggests dissociable systems (good memory + poor metacognition, or vice versa). K selected via BIC. Quality: silhouette > 0.40 threshold (may exceed Ch5 accuracy clustering due to richer 5-level data).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.1.4: results/ch6/6.1.4/data/step04_random_effects.csv. Ch5 cluster labels from 5.1.5 for comparison. Sample: N=100, 2 clustering variables (intercept + slope).
Analysis_Specification: (1) Load random effects from RQ 6.1.4. (2) Standardize to z-scores. (3) K-means K=1-6, select via BIC. (4) Fit final K-means (seed=42). (5) Validate: silhouette, Davies-Bouldin, Jaccard bootstrap. (6) Characterize clusters. (7) Cross-tabulate with Ch5 5.1.5 accuracy clusters. (8) Chi-square test of association.
Expected_Output: data/step01_standardized_features.csv; results/step02_cluster_selection.csv; data/step04_cluster_assignments.csv; results/step05_validation.csv; results/step06_characterization.txt; results/step07_ch5_crosstab.csv; results/step07_chi_square.csv; plots/step08_cluster_scatter.png
Success_Criteria: BIC minimum identified. Cluster sizes >= 10%. Silhouette computed (compare to 0.40 threshold). Ch5 crosstab and chi-square association test complete.

Title: Does calibration (confidence-accuracy alignment) change from Day 0 to Day 6?
Hypothesis: If confidence and accuracy decline in parallel, calibration should remain STABLE (no significant Time effect on calibration metric). If confidence lags behind accuracy decline, OVERCONFIDENCE emerges over time (calibration worsens). Calibration = Mean(Confidence) - Mean(Accuracy) per person per timepoint. Also: Brier score, Expected Calibration Error (ECE).
Data_Required: DERIVED: Accuracy theta from Ch5 5.1.1: results/ch5/5.1.1/data/step03_theta_scores.csv. Confidence theta from RQ 6.1.1: results/ch6/6.1.1/data/step03_theta_confidence.csv. Sample: N=100, 400 observations. Merge by UID × test.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load accuracy theta (Ch5) and confidence theta (Ch6). (1) Merge by UID × test. (2) Compute calibration: Calibration = theta_confidence - theta_accuracy (both z-standardized first). (3) Compute Brier score at item level. (4) Compute ECE (5 bins by confidence level). (5) Fit LMM: Calibration ~ Time + (Time | UID). (6) Test Time effect (does calibration worsen over time?). (7) Plot calibration trajectory.
Expected_Output: data/step01_merged_theta.csv (400 rows, theta_acc, theta_conf); data/step02_calibration_scores.csv (400 rows); data/step03_brier_scores.csv; data/step04_ece_by_time.csv (4 rows); results/step05_calibration_lmm.txt; results/step06_time_effect.csv; plots/step07_calibration_trajectory.csv
Success_Criteria: Merge successful (400 observations). Calibration computed per person-timepoint. Brier and ECE computed. LMM converged. Time effect tested with dual p-values (D068).

Title: Do people become overconfident as memories fade?
Hypothesis: Overconfidence (Calibration > 0, confidence exceeds accuracy) may INCREASE from Day 0 to Day 6 as accuracy declines faster than confidence adjusts. Test: significant positive Time × Calibration interaction. Secondary: Compute proportion of participants overconfident at each timepoint.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.2.1: results/ch6/6.2.1/data/step02_calibration_scores.csv. Sample: 400 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load calibration scores from 6.2.1. (1) Compute sign(calibration): overconfident (>0), underconfident (<0), calibrated (≈0). (2) Compute proportion overconfident at each timepoint. (3) Test trend: proportion overconfident ~ Time (logistic or linear). (4) Compute mean calibration by timepoint. (5) Plot overconfidence trajectory.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_classified.csv (400 rows, sign); results/step02_proportion_overconfident.csv (4 rows); results/step03_trend_test.csv; results/step04_mean_calibration.csv; plots/step05_overconfidence_trajectory.csv
Success_Criteria: Classification correct (3 categories). Proportion computed per timepoint. Trend test complete. Plot shows trajectory.

Title: Does discrimination ability (resolution/gamma) decline as memory fades?
Hypothesis: Resolution (ability to discriminate remembered from forgotten) may DECLINE from Day 0 to Day 6 as memory becomes noisier. Metric: Goodman-Kruskal gamma between confidence and correctness (item-level). Threshold: gamma > 0.50 = acceptable resolution.
Data_Required: Source: Raw item-level data from data/cache/dfData.csv. Both TQ_* (accuracy) and TC_* (confidence). Sample: ~68 items × 100 participants × 4 tests = 27,200 item-responses.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract item-level TQ_ (accuracy) and TC_ (confidence). (1) Compute gamma per participant per timepoint. (2) Fit LMM: gamma ~ Time + (Time | UID). (3) Test Time effect on resolution. (4) Compute mean gamma by timepoint. (5) Test if gamma stays > 0.50 threshold. (6) Plot resolution trajectory.
Expected_Output: data/step00_item_level.csv (27200 rows); data/step01_gamma_scores.csv (400 rows); results/step02_gamma_lmm.txt; results/step03_time_effect.csv; results/step04_mean_gamma.csv; plots/step05_resolution_trajectory.csv
Success_Criteria: Item-level data extracted. Gamma computed per person-timepoint. LMM converged. Time effect tested. Threshold comparison (gamma > 0.50) documented.

Title: Are high vs low performers equally well-calibrated?
Hypothesis: High baseline performers may be BETTER calibrated (metacognitive skill correlates with memory skill), showing smaller |calibration| and higher gamma. Test: interaction of Baseline_Accuracy × Calibration metrics. Alternative: Low performers are overconfident (Dunning-Kruger pattern).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.2.1: calibration scores. RQ 6.2.3: gamma scores. RQ 6.1.1: theta_confidence Day 0 (baseline). Ch5 5.1.1: theta_accuracy Day 0 (baseline). Sample: 100 participants.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load calibration (6.2.1), gamma (6.2.3), baseline accuracy (Ch5 5.1.1 Day 0). (1) Create accuracy tertiles (Low/Med/High baseline). (2) Compute mean |calibration| and mean gamma by tertile. (3) Test tertile effect: calibration metrics ~ Baseline_tertile. (4) Test Dunning-Kruger pattern (low performers overconfident). (5) Correlation: baseline accuracy vs calibration quality.
Expected_Output: data/step01_merged_metrics.csv (100 rows); data/step02_accuracy_tertiles.csv; results/step03_tertile_comparison.csv; results/step04_dunning_kruger_test.csv; results/step05_correlation.csv; plots/step06_calibration_by_accuracy.csv
Success_Criteria: Tertiles created. Calibration compared across tertiles. Dunning-Kruger hypothesis tested. Correlation computed.

Title: Does calibration decline faster for older adults?
Hypothesis: Age will NOT significantly moderate calibration trajectory (Age × Time interaction NULL), consistent with Ch5 universal age null pattern. Older adults may show lower baseline calibration (overall less accurate) but same trajectory slope.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.2.1: calibration scores. Age from data/cache/dfData.csv. Sample: 400 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load calibration + Age. (1) Center Age. (2) Fit LMM: Calibration ~ Time × Age_c + (Time | UID). (3) Test Age_c main effect and interaction. (4) Age tertile comparison. (5) Compare to Ch5 age null pattern.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_age.csv; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; data/step03_age_effects.csv; plots/step04_age_tertile_calibration.csv; results/step05_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. Age effects tested with dual p-values. Comparison to Ch5 age nulls documented.

Title: Do What/Where/When domains show different confidence decline patterns?
Hypothesis: NULL expected: Domain differences were NULL for accuracy in Ch5 5.2.1 (unitized encoding eliminates separation). If confidence parallels accuracy, domain × time interaction should be NULL. Possible exception: When domain (floor effect in accuracy) may show overconfidence (low accuracy but maintained confidence).
Data_Required: Source: data/cache/dfData.csv. Filter TC_* by domain tags: What (*-N-*), Where (*-L-*/*-U-*/*-D-*), When (*-O-*). Sample: N=100 × 4 tests × 3 domains = 1200 observations. Note: When domain may need exclusion due to Ch5 floor effects.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract TC_* by domain. (1) IRT Pass 1: 3-factor GRM (What/Where/When). (2) Purify (D039). (3) IRT Pass 2. (4) Merge theta_confidence with TSVR. (5) Fit LMM with Domain × Time. (6) Post-hoc: What vs Where, When vs others. (7) Compare to Ch5 5.2.1. (8) Note When domain status (exclude if <10 items after purification).
Expected_Output: data/step03_theta_confidence_domain.csv (1200 rows); results/step05_lmm_summary.txt; results/step06_domain_contrasts.csv; results/step07_ch5_comparison.csv; results/step08_when_domain_status.txt
Success_Criteria: IRT GRM for 5-category. 1200 observations. Domain × Time tested. Ch5 comparison. When domain status documented.

Title: Are people better calibrated for some domains than others?
Hypothesis: When domain may show BETTER calibration than What/Where despite floor effects: if both accuracy AND confidence are low, calibration = 0 (correctly uncertain). What/Where may show overconfidence (moderate accuracy but high confidence). Domain × calibration interaction.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Accuracy theta by domain from Ch5 5.2.1. Confidence theta by domain from RQ 6.3.1. Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load accuracy (Ch5 5.2.1) and confidence (6.3.1) by domain. (1) Merge by UID × test × domain. (2) Compute calibration per domain. (3) Fit LMM: Calibration ~ Domain × Time + (Time | UID). (4) Test Domain effects on calibration. (5) Identify best/worst calibrated domain.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_by_domain.csv (1200 rows); results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; results/step03_domain_effects.csv; results/step04_domain_ranking.csv; plots/step05_calibration_by_domain.csv
Success_Criteria: 1200 observations merged. Calibration by domain computed. Domain effects tested.

Title: Does age interact with domain for confidence decline?
Hypothesis: NULL expected: Age × Domain × Time 3-way interaction NULL, paralleling Ch5 5.2.3. Age-invariant confidence decline across all domains.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.3.1 + Age. Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load domain confidence + Age. (1) Fit LMM with Age × Domain × Time 3-way. (2) Test 3-way interactions. (3) Compare to Ch5 5.2.3.
Expected_Output: data/step01_lmm_input.csv; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; data/step03_interaction_terms.csv; results/step04_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. 3-way interactions tested. Ch5 comparison documented.

Title: Is confidence decline more trait-like for some domains?
Hypothesis: ICC_slope may differ by domain. If 5-level data reveals slope variance (per 6.1.4), some domains may show higher ICC_slope than others. Compare to Ch5 5.2.6 (all ICC_slope ≈ 0 for accuracy).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.3.1. Sample: 1200 observations (3 domains × 400).
Analysis_Specification: (1) Fit domain-stratified LMMs with random slopes. (2) Extract variance components per domain. (3) Compute ICC per domain. (4) Compare ICC_slope across domains. (5) Compare to Ch5 5.2.6.
Expected_Output: data/step02_variance_components.csv (15 rows); data/step03_icc_estimates.csv (9 rows); data/step04_random_effects.csv (300 rows); results/step05_domain_icc_comparison.csv; results/step06_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: All 3 domain models converge. ICC computed per domain. Ch5 comparison documented.

Title: Do Free Recall, Cued Recall, Recognition show different confidence decline?
Hypothesis: NULL expected: Paradigm differences were NULL for accuracy slopes in Ch5 5.3.1-5.3.2 (retrieval support affects baseline, not decay). If confidence parallels accuracy, paradigm × time interaction should be NULL. Recognition may show HIGHEST baseline confidence (retrieval support creates illusion of remembering).
Data_Required: Source: data/cache/dfData.csv. Filter TC_* by paradigm tags: IFR, ICR, IRE. Sample: N=100 × 4 tests × 3 paradigms = 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract TC_* by paradigm. (1) IRT Pass 1: 3-factor GRM (IFR/ICR/IRE). (2) Purify. (3) IRT Pass 2. (4) Fit LMM with Paradigm × Time. (5) Compare to Ch5 5.3.1. (6) Note if Recognition shows highest baseline confidence.
Expected_Output: data/step03_theta_confidence_paradigm.csv; results/step05_lmm_summary.txt; results/step06_paradigm_contrasts.csv; results/step07_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: 1200 observations. Paradigm × Time tested. Ch5 comparison documented.

Title: Are people better calibrated with more retrieval support?
Hypothesis: Recognition may show OVERCONFIDENCE: high retrieval support creates fluent retrieval that feels like remembering even when accuracy is only moderate. Free Recall may show best calibration (no false fluency from retrieval cues). Test: Paradigm × calibration interaction.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Accuracy from Ch5 5.3.1, Confidence from RQ 6.4.1. Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Merge accuracy and confidence by paradigm. (1) Compute calibration per paradigm. (2) Fit LMM: Calibration ~ Paradigm × Time. (3) Test if Recognition shows more overconfidence than Free Recall. (4) Rank paradigms by calibration quality.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_by_paradigm.csv; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; results/step03_paradigm_effects.csv; results/step04_recognition_overconfidence_test.csv; plots/step05_calibration_by_paradigm.csv
Success_Criteria: 1200 observations. Calibration by paradigm. Recognition overconfidence hypothesis tested.

Title: Does age interact with paradigm for confidence decline?
Hypothesis: NULL expected: Age × Paradigm × Time 3-way NULL, paralleling Ch5 5.3.4 (no differential aging effects across paradigms).
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.4.1 + Age. Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load paradigm confidence + Age. (1) Fit LMM with Age × Paradigm × Time. (2) Test 3-way interactions. (3) Compare to Ch5 5.3.4.
Expected_Output: data/step01_lmm_input.csv; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; data/step03_interaction_terms.csv; results/step04_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: Model converged. 3-way tested. Ch5 comparison.

Title: Is confidence decline more trait-like for some paradigms?
Hypothesis: Free Recall may show highest ICC_slope (most variability in challenging task). Compare to Ch5 5.3.7.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.4.1. Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Fit paradigm-stratified LMMs. (2) Extract variance components per paradigm. (3) Compute ICC per paradigm. (4) Compare to Ch5 5.3.7.
Expected_Output: data/step02_variance_components.csv; data/step03_icc_estimates.csv; results/step05_paradigm_icc_comparison.csv; results/step06_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: All 3 models converge. ICC compared across paradigms. Ch5 comparison.

Title: Do Common/Congruent/Incongruent items show different confidence decline?
Hypothesis: NULL expected: Schema effects were NULL for accuracy in Ch5 5.4.1. If confidence parallels, schema × time NULL. However: Congruent items may show HIGHER baseline confidence (schema-consistent feels familiar even if not better remembered).
Data_Required: Source: data/cache/dfData.csv. Filter TC_* by congruence tags: common (*-i1/*-i2), congruent (*-i3/*-i4), incongruent (*-i5/*-i6). Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract TC_* by congruence. (1) IRT Pass 1: 3-factor GRM. (2) Purify. (3) IRT Pass 2. (4) Fit LMM with Congruence × Time. (5) Compare to Ch5 5.4.1.
Expected_Output: data/step03_theta_confidence_congruence.csv; results/step05_lmm_summary.txt; results/step06_congruence_contrasts.csv; results/step07_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: 1200 observations. Congruence × Time tested. Ch5 comparison.

Title: Are people better calibrated for congruent items?
Hypothesis: Congruent items may show OVERCONFIDENCE: schema-consistent items feel familiar (high confidence) but may not be better remembered (Ch5 5.4.1 NULL). Incongruent items may show better calibration (less false familiarity). Test: Congruence × calibration interaction.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Accuracy from Ch5 5.4.1, Confidence from RQ 6.5.1. Sample: 1200 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Merge accuracy and confidence by congruence. (1) Compute calibration per congruence level. (2) Fit LMM: Calibration ~ Congruence × Time. (3) Test if congruent items show overconfidence.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_by_congruence.csv; results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; results/step03_congruence_effects.csv; results/step04_congruent_overconfidence_test.csv
Success_Criteria: 1200 observations. Calibration by congruence. Overconfidence hypothesis tested.

Title: Do schema-incongruent items produce more high-confidence errors?
Hypothesis: Incongruent items (schema-violating) may generate more high-confidence WRONG answers due to schema-based intrusions (remembering what "should" be there rather than what was). DRM effect analog. HCE = P(Accuracy=0 | Confidence >= 0.75).
Data_Required: Source: Item-level data from data/cache/dfData.csv. Both TQ_* and TC_*. Sample: ~27,200 item-responses.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract item-level TQ_ and TC_. (1) Identify high-confidence errors: Accuracy=0 AND Confidence >= 0.75. (2) Compute HCE rate per congruence level per timepoint. (3) Test Congruence × Time effect on HCE rate. (4) Compare congruent vs incongruent HCE rates.
Expected_Output: data/step00_item_level.csv; data/step01_hce_flags.csv; results/step02_hce_rates.csv (12 rows: 3 congruence × 4 tests); results/step03_congruence_hce_test.csv; plots/step04_hce_by_congruence.csv
Success_Criteria: Item-level data extracted. HCE defined and computed. Congruence effect on HCE tested.

Title: Do high-confidence errors increase from Day 0 to Day 6?
Hypothesis: High-confidence errors (HCE: Confidence >= 0.75 AND Accuracy = 0) may INCREASE over time as memories degrade but confidence doesn't fully adjust. Memory distortion + metacognitive failure. Test: significant positive Time effect on HCE rate.
Data_Required: Source: Item-level data from data/cache/dfData.csv. Both TQ_* and TC_*. Sample: ~27,200 item-responses.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract item-level TQ_ and TC_. (1) Compute HCE rate per participant per timepoint. (2) Fit LMM: HCE_rate ~ Time + (Time | UID). (3) Test Time effect on HCE rate. (4) Compute mean HCE rate by timepoint.
Expected_Output: data/step00_item_level.csv; data/step01_hce_rates.csv (400 rows); results/step02_hce_lmm.txt; results/step03_time_effect.csv; plots/step04_hce_trajectory.csv
Success_Criteria: HCE rate computed. LMM converged. Time effect tested.

Title: Who makes high-confidence errors? Individual difference predictors of HCE.
Hypothesis: Low baseline performers may make more HCEs (poor memory + poor metacognition = Dunning-Kruger). High confidence bias individuals may make more HCEs. Age may NOT predict HCEs (paralleling Ch5 age nulls). Predictors: baseline accuracy, baseline confidence, age, confidence bias.
Data_Required: DERIVED: HCE rates from 6.6.1. Baseline accuracy from Ch5 5.1.1 Day 0. Baseline confidence from 6.1.1 Day 0. Age from dfData.csv. Confidence bias = Mean(confidence) - Mean(accuracy) at Day 0.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load HCE rates + predictors. (1) Compute individual-level HCE rate (mean across timepoints). (2) Regression: HCE_rate ~ Baseline_accuracy + Baseline_confidence + Age + Confidence_bias. (3) Identify significant predictors. (4) Effect sizes for each predictor.
Expected_Output: data/step01_predictor_data.csv (100 rows); results/step02_regression_summary.txt; results/step03_significant_predictors.csv; results/step04_effect_sizes.csv
Success_Criteria: Regression converged. Predictors tested. Effect sizes computed.

Title: Are high-confidence errors domain-specific (more for What vs Where)?
Hypothesis: When domain may show MOST HCEs due to floor effects (low accuracy) combined with guessing (which may feel confident). What/Where may differ if object vs spatial memory have different metacognitive access.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Item-level data with domain tags. Sample: ~27,200 item-responses.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract item-level TQ_ and TC_ by domain. (1) Compute HCE rate per domain per timepoint. (2) Fit LMM: HCE_rate ~ Domain × Time + (Time | UID). (3) Test Domain effects. (4) Rank domains by HCE rate.
Expected_Output: data/step01_hce_by_domain.csv (1200 rows); results/step02_domain_hce_lmm.txt; results/step03_domain_effects.csv; plots/step04_hce_by_domain.csv
Success_Criteria: HCE by domain computed. Domain effects tested.

Title: Does high initial confidence predict slower forgetting?
Hypothesis: High Day 0 confidence may predict slower forgetting slope (well-encoded items have both high confidence and slower decay). Test: Day0_confidence × forgetting_slope correlation. Alternatively, confidence may NOT predict forgetting if metacognitive judgments are imperfect.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Day 0 confidence from 6.1.1 (theta at T1). Forgetting slope from Ch5 5.1.4 random slopes.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load Day 0 confidence and forgetting slopes. (1) Compute correlation: Day0_confidence vs slope. (2) Test if high confidence predicts slower forgetting. (3) Tertile analysis (High/Med/Low confidence, compare slopes).
Expected_Output: data/step01_predictive_data.csv (100 rows); results/step02_correlation.csv; results/step03_tertile_slopes.csv; plots/step04_confidence_predicts_forgetting.csv
Success_Criteria: Correlation computed with dual p-values. Tertile comparison. Direction of effect documented.

Title: Do people with variable confidence show variable memory?
Hypothesis: High within-person confidence variability (SD of confidence across items) may predict high within-person accuracy variability. Metacognitive noise may reflect encoding noise. Test: SD_confidence vs SD_accuracy correlation.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Item-level confidence and accuracy. Compute within-person SD at each timepoint.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Compute within-person SD of confidence per timepoint. (1) Compute within-person SD of accuracy per timepoint. (2) Correlate SD_confidence vs SD_accuracy. (3) Test if variability predicts variability.
Expected_Output: data/step01_sd_confidence.csv (400 rows); data/step02_sd_accuracy.csv (400 rows); results/step03_correlation.csv; plots/step04_variability_correlation.csv
Success_Criteria: SD computed. Correlation tested. Direction documented.

Title: Are well-calibrated people more stable forgetters?
Hypothesis: Good calibration at Day 0 may predict more predictable (less variable) forgetting trajectories. Metacognitive skill may correlate with stable consolidation. Test: Day0_calibration vs trajectory_variability.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Day 0 calibration from 6.2.1. Trajectory variability = residual SD from LMM in Ch5 5.1.1.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load Day 0 calibration and trajectory residuals. (1) Compute individual trajectory variability (SD of residuals). (2) Correlate Day0_calibration vs variability. (3) Test if good calibration predicts stable trajectories.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_variability.csv (100 rows); results/step02_correlation.csv; plots/step03_calibration_predicts_stability.csv
Success_Criteria: Correlation computed. Direction documented.

Title: Do source (-U-) and destination (-D-) locations show different confidence decline?
Hypothesis: Destination may show faster confidence decline (matching Ch5 5.5.1 accuracy pattern). Source-destination dissociation should replicate in confidence if it reflects fundamental memory processing difference. Test: LocationType × Time interaction.
Data_Required: Source: data/cache/dfData.csv. Filter TC_* to -U- (source) and -D- (destination) tags. Sample: N=100 × 4 tests × 2 locations = 800 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Extract TC_* for -U- and -D- items. (1) IRT Pass 1: 2-factor GRM. (2) Purify. (3) IRT Pass 2. (4) Fit LMM with LocationType × Time. (5) Compare to Ch5 5.5.1.
Expected_Output: data/step03_theta_confidence_location.csv (800 rows); results/step05_lmm_summary.txt; results/step06_location_contrasts.csv; results/step07_ch5_comparison.csv
Success_Criteria: 800 observations. Location × Time tested. Ch5 5.5.1 comparison.

Title: Are people better calibrated for source or destination memory?
Hypothesis: Source may be BETTER calibrated (lower uncertainty about pick-up locations, where initial object identification occurs). Destination may show overconfidence (put-down is automatic, feels familiar but decays faster). Test: LocationType × calibration.
Data_Required: DERIVED: Accuracy from Ch5 5.5.1, Confidence from RQ 6.8.1. Sample: 800 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Merge accuracy and confidence by location type. (1) Compute calibration per location. (2) Fit LMM: Calibration ~ LocationType × Time. (3) Test which location is better calibrated.
Expected_Output: data/step01_calibration_by_location.csv (800 rows); results/step02_lmm_summary.txt; results/step03_location_effects.csv; plots/step04_calibration_by_location.csv
Success_Criteria: 800 observations. Calibration by location. Location effect tested.

Title: Does confidence ICC reveal the same opposite-correlation pattern as accuracy?
Hypothesis: CRITICAL: Ch5 5.5.6 found OPPOSITE intercept-slope correlations (Source r=+0.99 regression to mean, Destination r=-0.90 fan effect). If this replicates in confidence, it validates fundamentally different forgetting dynamics. Test: intercept-slope correlations per location type.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.8.1. Sample: 800 observations.
Analysis_Specification: (1) Fit location-stratified LMMs with random slopes. (2) Extract variance components per location. (3) Compute intercept-slope correlations per location. (4) Compare to Ch5 5.5.6 (Source r=+0.99, Dest r=-0.90).
Expected_Output: data/step02_variance_components.csv (10 rows); data/step04_random_effects.csv (200 rows, REQUIRED for 6.8.4); data/step05_intercept_slope_correlations.csv; results/step06_ch5_comparison.csv (CRITICAL)
Success_Criteria: Both models converge. Intercept-slope correlations computed. CRITICAL: Ch5 5.5.6 comparison (opposite pattern replication test).

Title: Does confidence clustering replicate the strong 4-cluster structure found for accuracy?
Hypothesis: Ch5 5.5.7 was the ONLY clustering RQ to achieve Silhouette >= 0.40 threshold. If confidence clustering also achieves good quality, source-destination is genuinely special for individual differences. Test: silhouette for confidence clustering.
Data_Required: DERIVED from RQ 6.8.3: random effects (200 rows). Sample: N=100, 4 clustering features.
Analysis_Specification: (0) Load random effects from 6.8.3. (1) Standardize. (2) K-means K=1-6, BIC selection. (3) Fit final K-means. (4) Validate: silhouette, DB, Jaccard. (5) Compare to Ch5 5.5.7 (silhouette=0.417, 4 clusters). (6) Cross-tabulate with Ch5 clusters.
Expected_Output: data/step01_standardized_features.csv; results/step02_cluster_selection.csv; data/step04_cluster_assignments.csv; results/step05_validation.csv; results/step06_ch5_comparison.csv; results/step07_crosstab.csv; plots/step08_cluster_scatter.png
Success_Criteria: Clusters identified. Silhouette computed (compare to 0.40 threshold and Ch5 0.417). Ch5 crosstab computed.
